text: We'll hear argument next in No. 87-2066, W.S. Kirkpatrick & Company versus Environmental Tectonics Corporation.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Certainly there is nothing in the act of state doctrine that would require a United States court to refrain from examining Nigerian law--
No.
Good morning, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Mr. Rutter--
Yes, sir.
--it is correct though, isn't it, that they may well have a defense that you wouldn't have had the contract unless you were willing to engage in the same kind of conduct?
No, sir, I don't agree with that.
No, it's not in pari delicto.
--It is, Mr. Justice Stevens.
That's not the point.
Well, the second answer is that, first of all, how will they prove it.
Well, I'm not trying to predict how the case will come out.
That may be so, but Mr. Justice Stevens--
And I don't know if that makes any difference, but at least it's certainly something we have to think about.
--I don't think it makes any difference and I would suggest to you, sir, that it really makes no difference when you look at what the Republic of Nigeria has done in response to my request.
Mr. Rutter, can I come back to the suggestion you're making as to how we ought to handle act of state cases.
No, Mr. Justice Scalia, I obviously did not say what I intended to say which is--
Or I didn't hear what you intended me to hear, I'll put it that way.
--Well, if you look at the last few pages of our brief, I think I've said it there at greater length and perhaps with greater persuasion.
Because they knew the court wouldn't listen to--
In any event, sir, my proposed procedure, as set forth in the brief and as proposed here is simply this on the over-arching rule.
Well, what standards does the State Department follow in deciding whether or not to give such a letter?
I think those are matters remitted to the Executive Branch.
Well, I'm assuming that in making that judgment we're saying that the State Department has or has not followed an appropriate policy.

--May I, with deference, Mr. Justice Kennedy, disagree with that because the political issues which would be involved in the State Department's decision in whether or not to write such a letter are not matters that are properly within the purview of the judiciary, even of this Court.
What if the State Department says, go right ahead?
Then the court goes ahead, sir.
No matter what?
Yes, sir.
It doesn't... the court then doesn't ask any questions?
No, sir, because, again, as I've said to Mr. Justice Kennedy, the political questions that would be involved in "embarrassment"--
Well, you say then in this case the... the case is over because you have a representation from the State Department to go ahead.
--Yes, sir.
Even if this is... even if this is an act of state, go ahead.
--Even if it's an act of state, yes sir.
Which was the case in Citibank.
Yes, sir.
And what if the State Department says, sorry, no comment?
There, again, sir, I suggest that given the proper application of the rule that the case goes forward.
Well, that's a... you do say, then, that that takes a reworking of our past cases?
Absolutely.
Well, I know, but I was the sole dissent.
Well,--
So, I wouldn't mind reworking it, I suppose.
--That's exactly right, Mr. Justice White.
And the Court went ahead and held that the act of state doctrine applied.
--But let me remind you of the further history because that then suggest to me why the reworking along the lines I have suggested is necessary.
Yes, but you certainly are making an argument you don't need to make--
Absolutely, Mr. Justice--
--to win this case.
--Absolutely.
I don't know why you'd want to carry a big load like that.
I'm doing it, sir, because I have said that there are several levels at which this case can be decided.
Well, just on the Bernstein letter you--
--Yes, sir.
--just on the State Department's representation.
Yes, sir.
No matter what else is true.
Absolutely, Mr. Justice White.
You don't even have a very good Bernstein letter, though.
But as you said--
The State Department says, go right ahead because, as we read the law, the act of state doctrine doesn't apply.
--Absolutely not.
But what it then goes on to say... although I've got to admit it's going to embarrass the devil out of us, so be very careful--
It may embarrass--
--that seems to me to be a reverse Bernstein letter.
--Well, it's good enough for my purposes to satisfy the Bernstein exception, hence I rely upon it, Mr. Justice Scalia.
He said, we do mind, but as we read the law, the act of state doctrine doesn't apply.
--Well, I... in deference--
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Excuse me.
--I think American Banana at least provides some indirect support for that, Justice Scalia.
Wouldn't it have had to?
--No.
Well, if the Court please, first, with regard to the second letter that was received from the State Department, I don't think there is any material difference between the two letters.
Thank you, Mr. Brodsky.
